title: Swift Cheatsheet
subtitle: Simplest Swift's syntax reference to read whenever you forgot them
description: So I have spent some time to take a look at Swift's syntax and I decided to make a cheatsheet for myself in case I forgot them when I am coding in the future...
author: Chris Liu
content:
So I have spent some time to take a look at Swift's syntax and I decided to make a cheatsheet for myself in case I forgot them when I am coding in the future. I don't want to search and crawl the documentation all over again LOL. I write the following cheatsheet with reference to Learn Swift Fast (2020) - Full Course For Beginners.
Basics and Data Types
{`// Variable Declaration var str = "Hello World!" // Constant Declaration let constStr = "Hello World!" // 5 main data types var string: String = "String" var integer: Integer = 1 var float: Float = 0.1 var double: Double = 0.1 var boolean: Bool = true // Print something out print(string + "testing")`}
Operators
{`var a = 1 var b = 1 var c = 1.5 a = a * b * a pow(a, b) sqrt(a) ceil(c) floor(c) a += 1 a -= 1 a *= 1 a /= 1 // a = a % 1 = a mod 1 a %= 1`}
If and Switch
{`let a = 25 let b = 10 let c = 1 // If-else conditional statement if (a <= 10 || b > 5) || c != 1 { print("case 1") } else if (a < 15) { print("case 2") } else { print("case 3") } let chr = "a" // Switch conditional statement switch chr { case "a": print("It is a") case "b": print("It is b") default: print("Default") }`}
Loops
{`// For Loop for i in 1...10 { print("i") } var counter = 10 // While and Repeat-while loop while counter > 5 { counter -= 1 } repeat { counter -= 1 } while counter > 0`}
Functions
{`// Void function func printSomething() { print("Running function printSomething()" } // Function that will return value func returnSomething() -> Int { return 1 } // Function that have argument labels on parameters func addTwoNumbers(arg num1: Int, arg2 num2: Int) -> Int { return num1 + num2 } let sum = addTwoNumbers(arg: 1, arg2: 2) // Function that have no argument labels func addTwoNumbers(num1: Int, num2: Int) -> Int { return num1 + num2 } let sum = addTwoNumbers(num1: 1, num2: 2) // Function that does not require parameter name when called func addTwoNumbers(_ num1: Int, _ num2: Int) -> Int { return num1 + num2 } let sum = addTwoNumbers(1, 2)`}
Array
{`var array: [Int] = [1, 2, 3] // How to loop an array for i in 0...array.count - 1 { print(array[i]) } for item in array { print(item) } // How to declare empty array var emptyArray: [Int] = [] var emptyArray2 = [Int]() // Add item array.insert(4, at: 2) array += [5, 6] array.append(7) // Remove item array.remove(at: 0) // Search array array.firstIndex(of: 4)`}
Dictionary
{`var dictionary = [String:Int]() // Assigning data into dictionary dictionary["Chris"] = 18 dictionary["anotherChris"] = 20 dictionary["thirdChris"] = 22 // Retrieve value as optionals let myAge = dictionary["Chris"] // Remove a key-value pair dictionary["Chris"] = nil // How to loop a dictionary for (key, value) in dictionary { print("\(key) is \(value) years old") }`}
Optionals
{`// An optional data type (?) allows "nil" to be a value for that variable or constant var a: Int? = nil // d can store a string or nil, but already unwrapped var d: Int! class Testing { func markSix() -> Int { return Int.random(in: 1...10) } } let b: Testing? = Testing() // Check if the optional variable contains something if b != nil { // Before accessing the optional variable // We need to unwrap the optional like this print(b!.markSix()) } // Optional binding if let c = b { print(c.markSix()) } // Optional chaining b?.markSix()`}
Class
{`// Base class class Employee { var name: String = "" var salary: Int = 0 var role: String = "" var annualSalary: Int { return salary * 12 } // Constructors init() { name = "Employee" } init(_ name: String) { // So that there won't be naming conflicts self.name = name } func toString() { print("My name is \(name) and my salary is \(salary).") } } var chris: Employee = Employee() chris.name = "Chris" var anotherChris: Employee = Employee("Chris") // Inheritance class Manager: Employee { var teamSize = 0 override init(_ name: String) { super.init(name) teamSize = 10 } override func toString() { super.toString() print("I have a team of \(teamSize) people.") } } var m: Manager = Manager("Manager") `}
Designated and Convenience initializer
{`class Square { var name: String var weight: Int? // Designated initializer // Ensure all properties are initialized init() { name = "Square" } // Convenience initializer convenience init(_ weight: Int) { // Call designated initializer to make sure object is ready to go self.init() // Initialize other members if you need self.weight = weight } }`}

title: Let's have a journey of mobile app development
subtitle: Entering the mobile world
description: So actually I have been quite interested in experiencing mobile app development for few years but I still haven't try it out when I am writing this paragraph LOL...
author: Chris Liu
content: <NormalText><BoldText>Disclaimer: I am just a guy that spent most of my time focusing on developing website. I am just writing this passage to record how I learn and try mobile app development. My views and comments could probably be VERY WRONG XD.</BoldText></NormalText><NormalText>So actually I have been quite interested in experiencing mobile app development for few years but I still haven't try it out when I am writing this paragraph LOL. From my understanding, the current trend of mobile app development can be seperated into 2 parts, <BoldText>native</BoldText> and <BoldText>cross-platform</BoldText>.</NormalText><Breakline /><Header>Native</Header><NormalText>Native means coding a mobile app by a specific language that targets to run on certain operating system. For example, <BoldText>Java</BoldText> and <BoldText>Kotlin</BoldText> for Android platform, <BoldText>Objective C</BoldText> and <BoldText>Swift</BoldText> for IOS platform. Since I am going to dig into IOS platform, I won't be exploring Java and Kotlin here.</NormalText><Image src="/ios/swift-vs-objective-c.jpg" alt="swift-vs-objective-c" /><NormalText>I found out there is quite an interesting story behind Objective-C.</NormalText><BulletList listItems={["In 1986, the inventors of Objective-C published a book about the design concept of the language, which marked the birth of Objective-C.", "Steve Jobs was abandoned by Apple and he founded another company called NeXT. NeXT bought the copyright of Objective-C in 1988 for developing AppKit and FoundationKit.", "Apple absorbed NeXT in late 1991 and Steve Jobs become CEO of Apple again.", "And probably you now understand how Objective-C became foundation of OS X. But obviously it is VERY OLD already and that's why Swift comes in."]}></BulletList><Breakline /><NormalText><BoldText>Swift</BoldText> was firstly introduced to public in 2014 WWDC(Apple Worldwide Developers Conference). Apple described the language as <BoldText>Modern, Interactive, Safe, Fast and Powerful</BoldText>. The version of Swift latest release is 5.2.2 already comparing to 1.0 in September 4, 2014. Seems I can conclude that Apple will continue to support the growth of this language and slowly replace Objective-C by looking at the continuous and stable update of the language over the past few years. So the next question would be, <BoldText>how good is Swift ?</BoldText></NormalText><NumberedList listItems={["Co-existance of Swift and Objective-C in the same project is just like C and C++. Developers can integrate them easily and freely.", "Swift supports cross-platform development for the Apple ecosystem, like iPhone, iPad, Apple Watch and Mac.", "Objective-C requires manual memory management and performs badly. Swift uses Automatic Reference Counting to manage memory, which in simpler words, means utilizing resources to the most efficient extent by auto memory management and eliminate those severe leakages and flaws.", "Swift uses simpler, cleaner and easier understandable syntax like Python.", "Speed performance was once a big issue and concern for Swift, but Apple is gradually carrying out optimization and improvement during update."]}></NumberedList><NormalText><BoldText>Errr...</BoldText> I can't think of a reason for myself to not learning Swift as a beginning to iOS development LOL. Before jumping into Swift, let's slightly investigate <BoldText>Cross-Platform</BoldText> development as well.</NormalText><Breakline /><Header>Cross-Platform</Header><NormalText>The main idea is just <BoldText>"Write once, Use everywhere"</BoldText>, which is what <BoldText>React Native says </BoldText> as well. When the target audience of your product are everyone that equipped with a cellphone, then probably you don't want to implement the same application flow in many different lanugages in order to support different platforms. In this case, cross-platform developing tools will suit you the best.</NormalText><Image src="/ios/react-native.png" alt="react-native" /><NormalText><BoldText>React Native</BoldText> was first released in March 2015. It allows developers to build Android and iOS apps in the same time with the help of <BoldText>Javascript</BoldText> and one of it's best UI framework <BoldText>React</BoldText>. As you can tell, it is promoting a React ecosystem that enables developers to use the same skill sets in both web and mobile app development. It greatly smoothen the learning curve for those programmers with web dev experience or even React foundation. Few years ago I have played around React Native for some time but the experience is not that good. There are bugs and performance issues but I am not sure what the current version looks like. You know things can improve a lot in few years.</NormalText><Breakline /><Image src="/ios/flutter.jpg" alt="flutter" /><NormalText>React Native is a product from <BoldText>Facebook</BoldText> while <BoldText>Flutter</BoldText> is supported by <BoldText>Google</BoldText>. Flutter was introduced to public in <BoldText>Google I/O 2017</BoldText> and released in 2018. It is a pretty new framework comparing to other cross-platform options. It has a pretty good performance due to the underlying <BoldText>Dart</BoldText> compiler and the direct communication between the platform and code. It does not need a bridge as middleman to communicate with system while React Native relys on Javascript. Flutter got a great future potential but just keep a certain distance from it first. You know Google likes to abort their projects suddenly in one day. Who knows XD. It certainly still needs some time to be mature.</NormalText><Breakline /><NormalText><BoldText>Alright... time for me to dig deeper into Swift. I will update my learning progress when I have time. See you next time :P</BoldText></NormalText>

title: How I stop manually deploying my site with updated components
subtitle: Solving problem by CI / CD
description: When I started coding this personal website weeks ago, I was too lazy to setup automatic deployment upon any new changes I made to the site. Soon I found that it was SO STUPID...
author: Chris Liu
content:
When I started coding this personal website weeks ago, I was too lazy to setup automatic deployment upon any new changes I made to the site. Soon I found that it was SO STUPID to manually run the deploy command every single time I commit new changes to the site. That's why I seek help from Circle CI.
So what is CI / CD ????
CI stands for Continuous Integration. So if I have set up a CI environment for my website, I can ensure the whole project will be built in the same environment and with the same versions of packages whenever I commited my code from anywhere. This can avoid the compatability issue of the update I made with the existing code base. Also, I can setup some tests for my commits acting as a second barrier before actually deploying.CD stands for Continuous Deployment. As you can tell from the words, it just means the server will help you in automatically deploying after all those checking and building in the above steps.
How do I make use of Circle CI ?
So basically I wrote a config.yml file under root folder .circleci.{`# Version of CircleCI version: 2.1 jobs: # Name of the job deploy-site: # Tell CircleCI that I need docker environment docker: # Specify the image I need - image: circleci/node:latest working_directory: ~/my-portfolio steps: - checkout - run: sudo npm install -g gh-pages # Download and cache dependencies to avoid installing package per commit - restore_cache: keys: - dependencies-{{ checksum "package.json" }} # Fallback to using the latest cache if no exact match is found - dependencies- - run: yarn install - save_cache: paths: - node_modules key: dependencies-{{ checksum "package.json" }} - run: yarn run build - run: git config --global user.email chrisliupascal@gmail.com - run: git config --global user.name nighostchris - run: yarn run deploy workflows: main: jobs: - deploy-site general: branches: only: - dev`}I wrote the above .yml by reading some documentation in Circle CI.And then I go to CircleCI...Register an account...Link CircleCI with my Github and push my codeSee if the config works...The reason of the error is that CircleCI needs a deploy key with greater priviledge, which is write access to repository in this case, to deploy the updated built site. So now I went to the project setting page...Click the Authorize with GitHub button...And now I can add a user key with higher priviledge. Run the CircleCI deployment process again...NICE!!! I don't need to worry about deploying my site with updates regularly now and focus on coding new stuffs and writing passages like this one XD. Thanks for reading. See you next time!
